result.execSummary:
The defendant Wayne A. Cooper was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • OWI 6th, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Concurrent with: Any probation now serving

Per Statute 343.301(g) your operating privileges for operation of Class D vehicles will require that vehicles owned and/or driven by you be equipped with an ignition interlock device.  Must install a mandatory Ignition Interlock Device when defendant obtains an occupational license or regular license.  There is a $50 ignition interlock surcharge imposed.

miscConds.notes: Fine and court costs have been paid in full out of cash bond on file.
Paid in full out of cash bond on file.

Defendant must execute all releases of information for assessments, counseling, treatment, to allow probation agent to verify compliance.  Defendant must attend and successfully complete the Ho-Chunk Nation Healing to Wellness Court Program.  Defendant must follow all rules in the treatment court participant handbook, and all rules imposed by the team.  Defendant must immediately identify himself as a treatment court participant to any law enforcement officer or medical personnel.  He must execute releases to the treatment court team for any medical treatment or appointments he has.  Defendant must also honor any no contact provisions set by agent, as well as any other conditions his agent may impose.

Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  Defendant shall not operate a motor vehicle until properly reinstated, insured, has IID installed, and your agent approves you to drive.

Must follows all probation rules, and recommendations for treatment, counseling, or programing by your agent.  Must remain on SCRAM unit until Healing to Wellness Treatment Court Team determines defendant can be taken off.

timeConds.notes: The 1 year jail term is stayed and is to be used for sanctions by the Ho-Chunk Healing to Wellnes Treatment Court Team.  If any sanctions ordered they are not to be served on SCRAM or with Huber privileges.  If the Healing to Wellnes  Treatment Court and probation are both successfully completed the remaining unserved balance of jail will be vacated.  Credit for 126 days served.

records.descr: Notice and acknowledge of def voting ineligibility

records.addlTxt: Associated with Charge #1
Judge told attorney Hertel it's not necessary to file waiver form.

Defendant appeared with counsel Harry Hertel.  Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Waived right to prelim after Judge reviewed right to prelim and what a prelim involves.  Waiver accepted and bound over for trial.  Proceeded to plea and sentencing.  Sentenced to probation with conditions.
and certificate of appearance served on Chief Earl Lemieux to appear at preliminary hearing.

Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  Defendant shall not operate a motor vehicle on the highways until properly reinstated in the State of Wisconsin.    As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request.  Defendant is to remain in jail until a bed is available for in-patient treatment through the Ho-Chunk Nation Healing to Wellness Court.  AMENDED 12-09-14:  May be released on a SCRAM and no longer will be going to in-patient treatment.  Must comply with all Ho-Chunk Nation Healing to Wellness Court Rules and programming.  Must also comply with all other alcohol conditions stated above.
Defendant appeared by video from the Jackson County Jail.  Melissa Inlow appeared for the State.  Bond conditions amended.  Copy of bond faxed to jail.
